message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is experiencing postpartum hemorrhage, which is a medical emergency. The most appropriate initial step would be bimanual massage to compress the uterus and stop the bleeding. Blood product transfusion may be necessary after initial interventions fail, but it is not the most appropriate initial step. Hysterectomy and uterine artery embolization are more invasive procedures that should only be considered if other measures fail.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The postpartum bleeding indicates postpartum hemorrhage, and the most appropriate initial step is bimanual massage to help control the bleeding. Blood product transfusion may be necessary if hemorrhagic shock occurs. Hysterectomy and uterine artery embolization are not initial management options for postpartum hemorrhage.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is experiencing postpartum hemorrhage, and bimanual massage is recommended as the first step in management to control the bleeding, followed by blood product transfusion if necessary. Hysterectomy and uterine artery embolization are more invasive procedures and are reserved for cases where other measures fail.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is experiencing postpartum hemorrhage, and the most appropriate initial step in management is bimanual massage to help identify the source of bleeding and to apply pressure to stop the bleeding. Blood product transfusion may be necessary after the source of bleeding is identified. Hysterectomy and uterine artery embolization may be considered if bimanual massage and other conservative measures are not successful in controlling the bleeding.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is experiencing postpartum hemorrhage and the initial step in management is bimanual massage to control bleeding. Blood product transfusion may also be necessary, but it is not the initial step. Hysterectomy and uterine artery embolization are more invasive procedures that may be considered if initial measures fail.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The situation suggests postpartum hemorrhage, and bimanual massage is the most appropriate initial step in management to try to control the bleeding. Blood product transfusion may be necessary if bleeding continues despite massage, and hysterectomy or uterine artery embolization may be considered if bleeding cannot be controlled.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s continued vaginal bleeding suggests postpartum hemorrhage. Bimanual massage, applying manual pressure on the uterus with one hand while the other hand compresses the uterus from above, is the most appropriate initial step in management to help the uterus contract and control the bleeding. Blood product transfusion, hysterectomy, and uterine artery embolization may be needed if the bleeding persists, but they are not the initial steps.

Blood product transfusion may be necessary if there is significant blood loss, but it is not the initial step. Hysterectomy and uterine artery embolization are more invasive procedures that may be considered if other measures fail.

The patient is experiencing postpartum hemorrhage, and the most appropriate initial step in management is bimanual massage to manually compress the uterus and control bleeding. Blood product transfusion and uterine artery embolization may also be necessary, but they are not the most appropriate initial step. Hysterectomy would only be considered if other interventions fail to control bleeding.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The continued bleeding after delivery suggests postpartum hemorrhage. Bimanual massage is the most appropriate initial step in management to help control the bleeding. Blood product transfusion may be necessary if bleeding continues. Hysterectomy or uterine artery embolization may be considered if other methods fail to control the bleeding.
